sn12.63:1.2: On the four fuels see SN 12.11. Here the Buddha drives home the suffering of dependency with a series of unforgettable similes.
sn12.63:2.9: In the Mahābhārata, Bhīṣma forcefully condemned meat eating, saying, “The meat of other animals is like the flesh of one’s child” (13.115.010c; cf. 13.148.017c). Some, however, believed a child’s flesh had magic potency (Kathāsaritsāgara 29d).
sn12.63:3.8: This reflection goes as far as non-return, because the focus is on the elimination of sense desire.
sn12.63:4.2: Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 3.1.2.13–17 explains that the cow was once naked, so the gods flayed man and clothed the cow with it. Now a man bleeds when cut even by grass, whereas a cow endures rain and cold and heat.
sn12.63:5.2: Such pits are frequently mentioned in the suttas and must have been a common sight. Since fired bricks were not regularly produced, perhaps they were used for metals or pottery, although kilns are also mentioned. Falling in one is an apt simile for the pains of hell (AN 7.66:8.3, SN 12.51:12.1).
sn12.63:6.23: This too is in reference to the sufferings undergone by consciousness in transmigration, especially in the hells (MN 129:8.2, SN 56.35).
